a.style: font-family:'Playfair Display', Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Liberation Serif', serif

text.tspan: Death rate from cancers vs. income inequality, 2020
The death rate (measured as the number of deaths per 100,000 individuals) refers to all forms of cancers and is
standardized for age to allow cross-country comparisons. The Gini coefficient is a measure of the inequality of the
income distribution in a population. Higher values indicate a higher level of inequality.
Note: Depending on the country and year, inequality data relates to either disposable income or consumption
Data source: IHME, Global Burden of Disease (2019); World Bank PIP
